Windows so if you have played around at person storage so far the support has

kubernetes typically your tublat as well as on the provisioning side in the controllers but through through an
initiative called CSI migration the overall idea is the community wants to get away from entry plugins in 2 out of
3 plugins delivered ideally through CSI now in the CSI model the idea is there
are controller plugins that allow you to provision storage attach it to certain nodes and things like that and then
there's this other critical piece called a CSI node plugin which needs to be deployed on each node that looks at the
disk devices figures of the volumes on them and services them to the actual workload containers so until now a lot
of this support has been done through entry plugins or flex volume scripts both of them are kind of going away from
the community 6 storage does not like them so CSI is a way forward and the way we
are enabling CSI support in Windows is using a privileged proxy binary that
sits in your host and allows arbitrary CSI node pods geared towards Windows to
communicate with the privileged proxy and get their privileged operations accomplished we have a talk right after
this in I think meeting room 7 a and B where we dive a lot more into this but
this is the general idea the CSI proxy is going to expose a whole bunch of API so it allows you to
anywhere a disk volumes mount SMB shares login to I scuzzy targets and so on some
of a broad array of common storage related operations that a container
that is published by a storage vendor can make use of pretty easily so yeah
it's the the bulk of this component is in the CSI proxy repo that we are working on it's completely out of tree
